awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Machine Learning-Based Burn Injury Diagnosis and Care
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of machine learning technology to evaluate patients with skin burns. The proposed software tool is designed to determine burn severities and surface area percentages quickly and accurately.  Currently, medical professionals use a visualized method to look at wounds and determine burn severities and to estimate burn percentage versus unburned skin.  This may result in a wait of 3-7 days during which time doctors determine the burn degree by comparing pictures from the first day and following days of continuous monitoring.  The proposed image processing and machine learning algorithm may provide clinicians with the ability to predict total burn surface area, expected resuscitation amount, delineate second- and third-degree burns, as well as prognosticate indeterminate-degree burns.  The proposed technology may reduce ICU cost for both patients and hospitals, and may allow for better, more efficient patient care, better survival, and better functional outcomes.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a machine learning algorithm to process imaging from burn patients.  The proposed assist tool is designed to determine the total body surface area of burns using an image capture technology.  Image capture technology may be used to calculate total body surface area based on image recognition of burned areas, providing physicians and other medical personnel with more objective data on which to base resuscitation.  In addition, the proposed technology may be used to delineate between full thickness and partial thickness of burn injuries.  Also, it may be used to delineate between operative and non-operative indeterminate thickness burn injuries. Burn wounds are always evolving, and based on the depth of a burn injury, an operation may be required. The lengthy observation period with current visual methods exposes patients to infection, hospital-related comorbidity, and life-altering hospital cost. Using image capture technology and machine learning to analyze a standardized image of burn injuries to delineate between operative and non-operative burns may mitigate these risks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Texas Tech University Health Science Center

por.por_cntn:
The project, funded by the NSF I-Corps Program, has developed an innovative assist tool for diagnosing and treating burn injuries using advanced image capture technology and machine learning algorithms. This technology accurately detects burn severity and coverage, significantly advancing medical diagnostics and treatment planning. The intellectual merit of our project lies in its contribution to scientific knowledge in biomedical engineering and machine learning, specifically through a novel method that calculates the total body surface area affected by burns and distinguishes between different burn depths. This enhances surgical decision-making and reduces risks associated with lengthy hospital stays. The tool's ability to perform accurate, remote assessments makes it invaluable for telemedicine, particularly benefiting rural and underserved communities.The broader impacts of this project are profound, encompassing social, economic, commercial, and educational domains. Socially, the tool reduces hospital stays and associated risks, providing emotional and financial relief to patients and families. Economically, it has the potential to save significant healthcare costs by shortening ICU durations and improving treatment precision. Commercially, it offers a cost-effective and portable solution that competes with more expensive technologies, providing a scalable tool that can be integrated into various healthcare settings, including urgent care and telemedicine. Educationally, the project engaged diverse students and researchers, enhancing their skills in applying cutting-edge technologies in real-world applications. This project's ongoing development and application continue to foster an innovative learning environment while pushing forward the boundaries of medical technology.


Last Modified: 05/30/2024
Modified by: Alan W Pang
